transportAdvice: Cork city centre is compact and walkable, with most major attractions reachable on foot; a local bus network serves the wider city and suburbs, and taxis are readily available throughout the day and night.

weather.description: Cold and frequently wet with short daylight hours, typical of an Irish winter.
Similar to January, cold and damp with occasional frost but days slowly lengthening.
Early spring brings slightly milder temperatures but rain remains frequent and winds can be brisk.
Noticeably brighter with longer days, though showers are still common and temperatures remain cool.
One of the more pleasant months with mild temperatures, longer evenings, and a mix of sun and showers.
Warm and green with long daylight hours, though overcast skies and occasional rain are still typical.
The warmest month of the year with the best chance of sunny spells, though rain is never far away.
Warm and often pleasant, similar to July, with long evenings and a moderate chance of showers.
Early autumn brings cooler temperatures and more frequent rain as summer fades.
Noticeably wetter and windier with shorter days and a distinctly autumnal feel.
Cold, grey, and rainy with limited daylight, marking the onset of winter conditions.
Cold and wet with the shortest days of the year, though the festive atmosphere in the city is lively.
